keyFactors.title: Hot Streak Continuation
keyFactors.description: Rookie TE had recorded at least 68 receiving yards in each of his previous four games, averaging 64.7 YPG entering Week 10. One of NFL's best rookie tight ends.

keyFactors.title: Primary Herbert Target
keyFactors.description: As primary TE for Justin Herbert, Gadsden received consistent volume and usage in Chargers' passing attack despite run-heavy offensive approach.

keyFactors.title: Steelers' Defensive Weakness
keyFactors.description: Despite Steelers' overall defensive strengths, their scheme allowed opportunities for athletic TEs in seam routes and middle-of-field targets.

riskFactors: Chargers' run-heavy approach in blowouts limits passing volume
Rookie TE volatility - hot streaks don't last forever
Potential for regression from four-game ceiling performances

playerStats.injury: Knee injury in Q3 (questionable to return, did not return)

quarterBreakdown.description: Gadsden caught 2 of 4 targets for 8 yards in first half. Chargers built lead but Gadsden was uncharacteristically quiet despite receiving targets.
INJURY. Caught 1 more pass for 5 yards before leaving game with knee injury. Made awkward step on blocking play and limped to locker room, ending night prematurely.
Did not return. Listed as questionable but never came back. Injury sealed prop's fate.

gameResults.whenMissed: Never approached line - stuck at 13 yards when injury occurred in Q3
gameResults.gamePace: Chargers' 25-10 blowout allowed LA to control clock and lean on defense rather than airing it out. Herbert spread ball efficiently, limiting reliance on rookie TE.

whatWentWrong.title: Injury Ended Night Prematurely
whatWentWrong.description: Knee injury in third quarter sealed this prop's fate. Gadsden caught 3 of 6 targets for 13 yards before awkward step on blocking play sent him to locker room.

whatWentWrong.title: Underperforming Even Before Injury
whatWentWrong.description: The 13 yards on 3 catches through nearly three quarters showed Gadsden wasn't hitting typical efficiency. Needed 54 yards but never approached that number even while healthy.

whatWentWrong.title: Blowout Game Script
whatWentWrong.description: Chargers' dominant game flow didn't require heavy reliance on rookie TE. Offensive balance and run-heavy approach in blowout limited his opportunities.

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: This was 60% variance (injury), 40% error. The four-game hot streak created recency biasâ€”assuming ceiling performances would continue indefinitely. While his role as primary Herbert target was real, rookie TEs experience volatility, and Chargers' run-heavy approach in blowouts limits passing-game props. The injury was unpredictable variance, but the prop was marginal even before that factor.

closingLineValue.verdict: Slight positive CLV - line moved toward over as market recognized Gadsden's hot streak and role as primary TE target.

keyTakeaways: Hot-streak props carry inherent regression risk, especially for rookies
Gadsden's four-game run of 68+ yards created narrative that baseline had shifted upward, but volatility remains for young players
Always discount recent ceiling performances when projecting props - recency bias is dangerous
In-game injuries kill props instantly - no pre-game analysis accounts for mid-game exits
Chargers' blowout approach (run-heavy, clock control) limited passing volume even before injury
Zero carries for first time all season signals complete offensive dysfunction
verdict: Recency bias prop that relied too heavily on hot streak continuation. Four-game ceiling run masked rookie TE volatility. Injury was unfortunate variance, but prop was questionable even pre-game given Chargers' tendency to limit passing in blowouts.
